urn:contentItem:5X80-7HS1-JB20-G22K-00000-00Information Services Group, Inc. Shareholder/Analyst Call - Final2019-10-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:01:37ZLexisNexis100919a12731263.763Information Services Group, Inc. Shareholder/Analyst Call - Final

Corporate Participants

* Clay Calhoun

Information Services Group, Inc. - Partner of Sourcing Advisory Service Line

* Robert Krohn

Information Services Group, Inc. - Partner & Healthcare Practice Lead

* Steven E. Hall

Information Services Group, Inc. - President of ISG EMEA & Partner of Digital Advisory Services

Conference Call Participants

* Andrew Thomas Bauch

Wolfe Research, LLC - Analyst

* Bryan C. Bergin

Cowen and Company, LLC, Research Division - Director

* Drew L. Kootman

Cantor Fitzgerald & Co., Research Division - Research Analyst

* Edward Stephen Caso

Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, Research Division - MD and Senior Analyst

Presentation

OPERATOR: Good day, and welcome to the 3Q 2019 Global ISG Index. This call is being recorded.

At this time, I would like to turn the presentation over to the Index host this quarter, Bryan Bergin at Cowen and Company. Please go ahead, sir.

BRYAN C. BERGIN, DIRECTOR, COWEN AND COMPANY, LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Okay. Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. My name is Bryan Bergin, senior analyst covering IT and business services at Cowen. We're very pleased today to be moderating ISG's 68th Quarterly Index Call. ISG's role as a leading adviser and influencer in global sourcing offers a unique view of the state of the outsourcing and as-a-service markets.

The company has been hosting the Index call for over 16 years, and it's really evolved with the industry. We find its position between enterprise buyers and solution providers enables us to really key in on the leading trends. And we often find that it sets a tone for the upcoming earnings season.

The format of the call today will be a presentation of the key trends by the ISG team for 30 or 40 minutes, and then we'll open up the call for questions from the audience.

I'm going to now pass it over to Steve Hall, Partner and President of ISG to kick us off. Steve?

STEVEN E. HALL, PRESIDENT OF ISG EMEA & PARTNER OF DIGITAL ADVISORY SERVICES, INFORMATION SERVICES GROUP, INC.: Great. Thanks a lot, Bryan. And welcome, everybody, to the ISG Global Index Conference Call. And again, thanks to everybody at Cowen and Company for hosting today.

As Bryan mentioned, I'm Steve Hall. I'm the Partner and President and Global Leader for our ISG Index. And with me today, I've got 2 special guests, Clay Calhoun, who's a Partner for ISG sourcing solutions in the Americas; and Bob Krohn, who's our ISG Partner that leads our health care practice.

So we recognize that today is Yom Kippur, that not everyone's able to join the live call. But we appreciate those that have joined and really understand the priorities of others on this solemn day of prayer and fast.

So this is our 68th Quarterly Index Call, which provides a snapshot of technology and sourcing trends in the marketplace. And of course, global recessions concerns continue amid uncertainties fed by Brexit, unrest in Asia, geopolitical events and trade and tariff wars. Customers are weighing in whether to invest for growth or support cost take-out still. Though companies want to be recession ready, they continue to spend money on creating digital products. I think generally, ISG is optimistic about the broader market. Digital is now mainstream. As we've said on the last several calls, we think those digital tailwinds are pretty strong despite some of the economic headwinds that we see.

So if we go to the key headlines, despite some pockets of unrest in various parts of the world, the commercial outsourcing market performed well overall. The annual contract value in the global combined market returned to double-digit growth, with as-a-service continuing to set new record highs, and managed services came in 7% higher than the third quarter last year.

The Americas ACV reached a new high. The managed services found us [splitting] again after a slow first half of the year. And in fact, the third quarter ACV was its best ever in the history of the Index. The as-a-service also rebounded after a sequential decline in the first 2 quarters of this year. The European market took a bit of a hit this quarter, but managed services ACV declined moderately. And the ACV -- the as-a-service performed better but has not yet broken through the $2 billion mark.

And Asia-Pacific was perhaps the brightest spot this quarter. The combined market ACV rose considerably and celebrated its third consecutive $2 billion-plus quarter. The managed services grew more than 30% due to stepped-up activity in China and India, and the as-a-service ACV continued to rise but not quite as fast as we've seen in previous quarters.

If we focused on the global commercial trends, we note that the quarterly combined market ACV has grown by $3 billion in just the last 2 years alone. Managed services ACV fell back a bit this quarter but still closed more than 400 awards as it's done for 7 quarters in a row. So by number and value, managed services is enjoying a high sustained activity.

The as-a-service ACV did break through the $7 billion mark for the first time, nearly doubling what it was 2 years ago. Much of that strength this quarter came from the Infrastructure-as-a-Service market, which totaled more than $5 billion in ACV and reached an all-time high for activity.

Year-to-date, the row of green arrows says it all. The combined market grew at a brisk pace compared to this time last year. Managed services' narrow 2% increase was against the robust 2018, and it was one of only the few times it exceeded $20 billion.

Infrastructure-as-a-service ACV stood at 27% increase, while Software-as-a-Service was at 9%. When we break out the year-to-date performance by function, we see the ACV of ITO dip up by 1% compared to a strong 2018, but the application space remains very active. This client dismantled their legacy IT architectures, focus on DevOps modernization, next-gen application development, enterprise automation and cyber security. The technology solution providers are bringing in new technology that improves quality, efficiency and cost-effectiveness, and we continue to see that over the next several years.

The BPO ACV has remained consistent between the 4 to 5 -- the $4.5 billion and $5 billion for the last several years, and it really remains in sort of that same space.

Software-as-a-Service ACV has ticked up steadily and has now surpassed $5 billion at the 9-month mark for the first time. The awards are getting larger, in part due to more strategic channel relationships and large enterprise adoption of SaaS. The conversations are becoming more portfolio-based as opposed to one-off product-related conversations.

The Infrastructure-as-a-Service has more than doubled over the past 2 years. Some very strong competitors are facing off depending on the geographic market-specific client base. AWS, which started with cloud-native and startups were on Microsoft focused on enterprise and productivity tools are in hot competition. And as more and more enterprises are bringing important workloads and enterprise-level workloads to the cloud. Moving from legacy IT to modern IT is no longer just an implementation exercise, it really involves the full value and process redesign, change management and cultural change for organizations.

So beginning this quarter, we're going to start parsing out how much of the value awarded in managed services has a digital component. So as we've said over the last -- probably the last 2 years, digital is really the key story of the industry. So what we're interested in is to really understand how digital has grown with more of the traditional service providers. So we realize that everyone has a different definition of digital. In this presentation, we're going to look at those contracts in which some form of cloud computing is included along with analytics and artificial intelligence.

By looking at the data on this relative basis, we see real meaningful trends that are correlated with what we've heard from providers as we've talked to the industry. So we examined what percent of transactions coming to award at the broader market have a digital-based scope. Then we laid out the charts to show how that trend has changed over time. The data shows the digital builds are fast becoming the new normal for the industry.

So in 3Q '19, you'll notice that 48% of the contracts awarded in the broader market have a digital-based scope, which is an all-time high for the quarter. And we believe there is high growth potential going forward.

So the client decides to source a slice of this $200 million deal to the competitor. We see this pattern repeating itself over and over again, and this is truly what the incumbent's dilemma is.

BRYAN C. BERGIN: Steve, anything you could share as far as behavior there?

STEVEN E. HALL: Yes. No, I think what you're going to continue to see, Bryan, is this focus on the transformation piece and new dollars coming in to spend. And the metric that I keep going back to is, again, sort of we've added $3 billion of new technology spend per quarter. And it's -- that's a significant number as you think about it. So again if we look at just IT budgets, I would expect those, especially if we see any kind of downturn, for those to be relatively flat, and you'll see some cost takeout and some different things there. But I think because we look at such a broader portfolio and even as I mentioned, almost 45% of the spend for the traditional managed services guys is now digital. I think the overall market is growing and that's going to increase sort of the technology spend coming to the market pretty significantly. I think that trend is going to continue. It just gets harder and harder for all of us to say, what's that IT spend versus sort of what's this broader technology spend. And it's the broader technology spend that I'm pretty optimistic about.

BRYAN C. BERGIN: Okay. Makes sense. Then just on the incumbent's dilemma, the displacers, are these generally more next-gen disruptive service providers? Or are you actually -- are you seeing large traditional players that just happen to be trading deals, so to speak?

STEVEN E. HALL: It's a great question and it's a really good mix. What I would say in general over the last 3 years, everybody has upped their game. So what used to be competitive but arguably commoditized, whether it was infrastructure or AMS or test deals, has truly become competitive both from a vertical standpoint, a geographical standpoint and a capability standpoint. And so what you seen now is if somebody got into a Gen 1 or a Gen 2 deal, and let's say it was banking with the example I use, but they weren't necessarily deep with banking experience or expertise but they happened to be really good at infrastructure management. As we go into the Gen 3 deals and more things open up, it allows those service providers with really strong vertical and industry expertise to be able to provide different offerings. So interesting enough, we're seeing some swapping of deals. I wouldn't say it was like we saw in early days where it was just swapping for costs, it's certainly swapping for capabilities. So I think it's the breakup that we're seeing more and more with different organizations having capabilities to expand there. So I would suspect to see sort of continued movement in our Breakthrough 15 as we go through that as more of those deals are awarded to different providers and capabilities.

And I think on that same side, I think you have to really watch the M&A activity closely here because that's really going to be very telling on what's happening in the market. So if I just look at Capgemini for example, Cap necessarily wouldn't have been able to compete in an engineering services deal or a breakup of those deals. But now with their acquisition of Altran and Ericsson's expertise, all of a sudden they rise to sort of the top of class on being able to do those engineering type deals and those types of things are changing the market. Even if you look at some of the acquisitions that VMware and Pivotal and Broadcom-Symantec, there's all these massive changes that are sort of changing how clients and how the service providers interact with each other. So I'm watching that space as much as anything to see how that influences the capabilities of the service providers.

BRYAN C. BERGIN: Okay. Makes sense. Last one for you just on the -- as far as the price downs, I think you mentioned the incoming providers are -- they're not in fear of revenue cannibalization. What level of price downs are you seeing in those deals?

STEVEN E. HALL: The price has held pretty steady. I think as I mentioned a couple of quarters ago, I think there's still some margin pressure on the service providers. But the margin pressure continues to have to do with the investments that they've had to make to be, lack of a better word, I'll say digital ready. But what I really mean by that is their ability to implement -- create and implement automation solutions, continue to invest in the AI, the machine learning that they need for a lot of their next-gen app structures, the partnerships and relationships and retooling that they've had to do to create new solutions with Azure and AWS. And those solutions, though we're seeing a really big uptick and we're seeing better value with those, we're still seeing a bit of margin compression on those because of all the investments. The price has been holding pretty steady. I think we're all sort of waiting a little bit to see the uptick or the value pricing on some of the digital transformation. And that hasn't come to the degree that we would expect this sort of across the industry yet. But I suspect we'll continue to keep an eye on that and see that as automation starts to continue -- and AI continue to take a broader piece of the market.

Bob, do you have anything -- are you seeing anything, Bob, on especially in healthcare on pricing for service providers?

ROBERT KROHN: Yes. I think it's consistent with exactly what you said, Steve. We've seen moderate price pressure on the larger deals, especially. We do see some hunger from new service providers trying to enter the space with niche applications and niche offerings. But I would say it's consistent with the overall industry.

STEVEN E. HALL: Okay, good. And Clay, anything unique from an Americas perspective?

CLAY CALHOUN: Well, I think what you talked about in the whole incumbent's dilemma where providers are coming in, we see some very material price differences, much lower from the new providers coming in, in order to get that business, and part of the reason for the delta is the incumbents are trying to maintain a level of margin, maintain a level of team and delivery style that they've built up over the years of being in those clients. And we've mentioned the cannibalization of it. But those new providers that are coming in, we're taking a different look at the solution, and the team and the approach and there's a pretty material price reduction that we're seeing going to those new providers.

STEVEN E. HALL: Yes. And I think, Bryan, that's actually a key point that Clay brings up because what we do see in general, and it's not necessarily just price reduction, but the creativity of some of the solutions is really having a dramatic increase or decrease in the price of the client. So it's not at all unheard of now to see 25% to 40% cost reduction because of the impact of cloud, or the impact of AI, or moving to a DevOps full stack environment, some of the technologies that we talk about have an absolute material impact on the cost of delivery. And that, we see with so many of these that oftentimes, as Clay says, you can't necessarily realize from an incumbent's standpoint for a host of reasons that we discussed.

BRYAN C. BERGIN: Okay. Operator, can we open it back up?

OPERATOR: Yes. We will now take our next question from Edward Caso from Wells Fargo.

EDWARD STEPHEN CASO, MD AND SENIOR ANALYST, WELLS FARGO SECURITIES, LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: I'm curious as clients deal with the digital transformation, are they bringing any of the prior outsourced work in-house while they work to sort of rethink their business into a digital format?

STEVEN E. HALL: Ed, that is an absolutely spot-on question. And the reason it's so intriguing is we've been talking a lot about the repatriation of services for sort of the last year, 1.5 years. So one of the interesting things in the market right now is this whole notion of IT getting closer to the business. And this whole idea of being product-oriented and co-creating things with the business. And so when you do this, a lot of the peers will say that you need to go to an agile enterprise, you need to co-locate people, you need to help build that. And that's difficult to do on a global model. So you'll see organizations say, "Okay, I want to repatriate these services. It's more critical to my business function and it's more critical to how I organize."

I think the challenge and let me say, we've seen some really good success with that. We have examples in the energy and utilities sector where organizations have repatriated services, restructured how they do work and has reduced their cost structure by 40%. And those are real base cases to do it and it's really interesting. In many cases, though, what we see is this sort of disconnect of reality between increasing your products and getting more tightly aligned with the business, driving out new solutions in doing that, but doing this in a cost-effective manner. And so what we really see, some repatriation of services, but more this sense, how do I try to do agile and DevOps and product-aligned organizations, sort of all these new buzzwords in this global delivery model. And this recognition that there is still a continuous race for talent, no single country, no single company, no single area has a lock on that talent. So how do you get the best across? And how do you create operating models to be able to do that? So I'm not seeing the big broad repatriation that we were -- sort of thought would be there a little bit, certainly with the GM news from 2016 and some others, but we're seeing pockets of it and it usually has to do with market differentiators now.

Clay, what do you see from the Americas perspective? Any difference there?

CLAY CALHOUN: Yes, so a little bit. When we were looking at repatriation, right, we see some services coming back as clients start to advance their capabilities and become more comfortable within a multi supplier model, they can bring in some of that back. Where we're seeing most of the work is when human labor is being replaced by digital labor. And then there is compression in the remaining human labor and those components of that labor gets then repatriated back into the company. So again, we're seeing the human labor being replaced by software. And then partial FTEs, partial components being brought back into the organization to be managed or as they move into more comfort within a multi supplier model, being able to deal with more of those services back.

EDWARD STEPHEN CASO: Just around RPA, which I don't think I heard today. Is anyone really able to scale RPA? Is it part of this in-house -- partial in-house shift? And are the service providers sort of figuring out how to do it such that they're doing it as opposed to the client doing it?

STEVEN E. HALL: Yes. Thanks, Ed, for that question as well. I think we're still in early innings for RPA, quite frankly. I think we've got a set of really strong solutions, we got some use cases and we're really just starting to scale. I think at the enterprise level, there's clearly challenges around identifying the right processes, which we're seeing some different solutions in the market come to bear. We're seeing challenges with the orchestration, as Clay mentioned, between human and robotics and what are the whole workflow there. So we're seeing some solutions there. And at the service provider standpoint, I think there's -- I don't want to call it leapfrog because I think they are integrating the RPA solutions, but I think what you're seeing is this integration of artificial intelligence and APIs and software at scale to rethink maybe some of those business processes, which is also impacting. And in many cases, I mean we're seeing lots and lots of RRP implementation that are -- there are starting to scale, but they're still not what we would consider broad scale where we're seeing thousands of licenses being sold, et cetera. But we are starting to see more and more of where the centers of excellence or the internal organizations are trying to implement that and using different service providers or integrators that help teach them how to do it and they'll take off on their own to do it. So I would say in general, it's still really early innings. I think we're going to continue to see an explosion of RPA. I think it will continue to be a really hot market for the next several years. And certainly, AI, AML and some of the things that we discuss with it are going to reshape it as we go forward.

Bryan, you probably have a great perspective on that as well given your perspective on the RPA market as well. Any comments from you?

BRYAN C. BERGIN: Yes. Steve, no, I think that's -- what you said was fair. The change management seems to be the biggest stall point that we find when we have to look at use cases, and certainly a lot of good solutions out there. It's just thinking about it holistically and at enterprise level and then being able to drive the change from the top, those seem to be where successful engagements are -- why they are working.

STEVEN E. HALL: Yes. Exactly, well said.

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) We will now take our next question from Andrew Bauch from Wolfe Research.

ANDREW THOMAS BAUCH, ANALYST, WOLFE RESEARCH, LLC: This is Andrew on for Darrin Peller. So one thing we've heard from clients over the last year or so was that some industries are less capable of shifting to hybrid and public cloud environments primarily due to regulatory concerns around data and things of the like. My question is are you seeing similar barriers in the market from this shift? And do you have any insights on whether these types of regulations are easing and kind of open the gateway to more cloud adoption?

STEVEN E. HALL: The easy answer right off the top, Andrew, is yes. I'm going to answer this one from a couple different perspectives, then I'm going to ask Bob to give a perspective from healthcare where there's certainly a very strict regulatory environment there.

So in general, absolutely, yes. We do hear that oftentimes and it's probably one of the biggest reasons that's kind of slowing down both SaaS adoption and movement to hyperscalers or to the public cloud providers. In general, though, I think the cloud providers are responding with on-prem capabilities. So both AWS, Google and Microsoft, all have solutions where they can bring in their cloud solution into the on-prem or into the data center. So you're seeing this real advent of hybrid cloud solutions that can give you sort of the best of the cloud with all the tooling, with the DevOps, with the things that we all talk about as being so great on-prem to get over some of the regulatory pieces. I think the hyperscalers are also working extremely well with the regulators to make sure that they get certified environments in place to be able to do that. And that seems to be going well.

I wish I could say that I see movement on the regulator side to do that. But I've been in Europe for the last almost 2 years now, and quite frankly, I sort of see just the opposite. I see a tightening up of the regulatory environment. I think data privacy, data sovereignty, some of the cybersecurity risks, et cetera continue to impact those decisions. And I'm not seeing that let up. And quite frankly, I think that's what impacting some of the slowness that we see, and not slowness because it's growing at a great rate, but the slower rate of growth that we see in Europe compared to the U.S. markets or even the Asia-Pac markets. That being said, there are some real concerns. And so those have to be addressed, and I think the hyperscalers and others are addressing those and will continue to address those.

Bob, any thoughts on you from a healthcare perspective?

ROBERT KROHN: I'm sorry, Steve, could you repeat the question? I lost connectivity for a minute.

STEVEN E. HALL: Yes. No worries. We're just interested in what's happening on the healthcare side with regard to the regulatory environment on moving workloads or broader adoption of the public cloud. There's a lot of noise in the system about it and what's sort of your perspective from a healthcare perspective?

ROBERT KROHN: So I think unilaterally our clients are migrating toward a hybrid cloud. I think a complete adoption of the public cloud is not something that we're seeing, nor do I expect we'll see so -- see it in the near future. That being said, the adoption of the hybrid cloud is rampant, especially in the larger players and also in the provider space. So public, no; hybrid, yes.

STEVEN E. HALL: Yes. And Andrew, I think the one other thing, and this goes back to why we look at the acquisition strategy so much in the M&A. If you looked at VMware, for example, and their announcement with AWS and their acquisition of Pivotal and their acquisition of Carbon Black, you could really say that VMware is sort of becoming part of that core solution for the hybrid cloud. And I think there's a number of players and announcements between Microsoft and AWS, and Google that are all focused on saying this hybrid cloud is a path forward. How long that will be there, I think is contested amongst some really smart people in the industry. But I think it does give a path forward for everybody to sort of get the benefits that the cloud is certainly providing.

ANDREW THOMAS BAUCH: Got it. Appreciate the insight. And then my follow-up is, last quarter, you said one of the themes was uncertainty is the new norm from a macro perspective. So my question is, should we be taking this comment as business leaders are becoming more confident in making technology investments and spend decisions amidst a more challenging macro backdrop? And has that changed from quarter-to-quarter?

STEVEN E. HALL: I think we -- no, I think that's fair. I mean as I was starting the call, I talked about some of the macroeconomic issues and some of the global uncertainty. And I think that's just grown, right. I mean I think from the last call, we've had the October 31 Halloween date for Brexit, we've had Hong Kong issues, the trade tariff discussions continue. We've had Turkey today, and Syria, we've got impeachment discussions with Trump in the U.S. so there's tremendous amount of uncertainty in the markets right now. But again, when I look at the core of businesses, what the core of businesses are saying, the most underlying thing that's impacting me is this need to connect and get closer to my clients and my consumers, right. So and that's really the core of what's driving, again this whole digital transformation.

That drive is not going away. And as we've seen, if you're not investing in those areas and not driving whether it's IoT or autonomous driving our electrification, the big megatrends that are really impacting our industry. Then your Board is going to force some decisions to be able to do that. So I think honestly from a tech standpoint, those drivers are still incredibly strong in the market. And despite some of the uncertainty, I think boards and senior technology leaders are just sort of getting on with it. I know certainly from a local perspective here in London, though there's lots of concerns, I think there's this sense, it's just time to get on with it. I've got a business to run and let's go do that. And that's what I'm getting from most of the business leaders and what I'm seeing generally across the business segment. There are some markets where that's probably a little bit different. So that helps.

ANDREW THOMAS BAUCH: Yes. It just seems that playing defense is maybe more of a risky strategy than playing offense these days, but appreciate the color.

STEVEN E. HALL: Yes. No, I think you're right and I think what you're seeing is that you've got a lot more offensive players making the technology calls right now.

OPERATOR: There appears to be no further questions over the telephone. (Operator Instructions) There appears to be no further questions over the telephone.

STEVEN E. HALL: Great. Well, thank you so much, operator. And I just want to thank everybody again for today's call. As always, really good insights from everybody on the call on what's happening. We appreciate providing the insights back to the market.

Our next call will be January 14. So please register and sign up for the first quarter index -- or the fourth quarter, being the first quarter of 2020, where we'll have broader insights on the year. And as we said, we'll really highlight what it takes for some of the startups and the competitors to really start winning more business. So that will be the special insights for that one.

And with that, Bryan, I again want to thank you and your team for sponsoring it. And I hope everybody has a wonderful day. Thank you.

OPERATOR: This concludes today's call. Thank you for your participation, ladies and gentlemen. You may now disconnect.

Information Technology And Innovation Foundation Holds Discussion On Technology And Antitrust Issues

July 11, 2019 10:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION FOUNDATION PRESIDENT ROBERT D. ATKINSON

BLOOM STRATEGIC COUNSEL FOUNDER SETH BLOOM

INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY COUNCIL CEO JASON OXMAN

INTERNATIONAL CENTER FOR LAW AND ECONOMICS RESEARCH FELLOW ALEC STAPP

BERKMAN CENTER FACULTY AFFILIATE THIBAULT SCHREPEL

INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY AND INNOVATION FOUNDATION PRESIDENT ROB ATKINSON

INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY COUNCIL PRESIDENT JASON OXMAN

[*]ATKINSON: Alright, well, good morning, everyone. I'm Rob Atkinson, President of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, and I wanna welcome you to an event on how we should we be thinking about this increasing furor about breaking up big tech. So we have a great panel this morning. Before I introduce them, I do wanna make a few opening and framing remarks, and then we'll just jump into this great panel. And we should have at least 20 or 30 minutes for questions and conversation, from you all. Also wanna mention, I--I can't resist, since we're talking about tech, we have a great event next week, on Wednesday?

UNKNOWN: Tuesday.

ATKINSON: Tuesday, up on Capitol Hill, on the role of robotics in technology innovation. And speaking of robots, there will be a robot there that will actually introduce me, so that's kind of cool, if you've ever seen Pepper the robot. So they'll actually be Pepper, there will be another robot there, so it's a fun event, it's on our website. So, there's been an increasing debate really in the last couple of years.

You see it now, with some of the presidential candidates on the Democratic side, but certainly others who are concerned about the purported power, market power of large technology firms. And there are in--in any trust circles, there's sort of two ways to think about market power. One is structural remedies, and one is conduct remedies. And historically, the focus has been on conduct remedies. If you think about the Microsoft case, back in the late '90s and 2000, the Microsoft case was a conduct remedy.

There was an assertion that Microsoft was using its power over--over Windows and Office, to hurt competitors. And so the remedy was that they had to fix that, which they did. There were people at the time pushing a structural remedy, which would be to break up Microsoft somehow. And structural remedies are largely seen as kind of a--a last resort. We did it with AT&T, we did it with Standard Oil. But by and large, antitrust authorities have not embraced that. Now what we're seeing though is an increasing focus on, perhaps we need structural remedies, which ITIF would disagree with.

There are lots and lots of reasons why "Market power," in these industries is actually pro-innovation and pro-consumer. Let me read two quotes from you that I think put this in perspective, both from the Obama Administration Council of Economic Advisors, in a report they talked about market power and--and innovation. The first quote says "Allowing firms to exercise the market power they have acquired legitimately can maintain incentives for research and development, new product introduction, productivity gains, and entry into new markets, all of which promote long-term economic growth."

And we certainly see that today. If you look at the top 15 firms in the world, in terms of R&D investment, six of them are American tech companies: Amazon, Alphabet, Microsoft--I'm sorry, five, Apple and Facebook. These five companies invest more in R&D--invest seven times more in R&D than the National Science Foundation. And they're able to do that, because they have scale economies.

The second quote from the Obama Administration is--it says "Some newer technology markets are characterized by network effects, with large positive spillovers from having many consumers use the same product. Markets in which network effects are important, such as social media sites may become dominated by one firm." How many people here use Facebook? How many people would like the government to make you use Facebook, and Headbook (PH)? In other words, you now have to post twice on a social media site, because having one only is a--is a monopoly. The answer is obviously, you don't wanna do that.

How many people buy on Amazon? Yeah, I would be surprised if there's--how many people don't buy on Amazon? (INAUDIBLE) zero. Did I see a hand go--oh, good, alright. And--and--and how many people would like to when you go on Amazon--I--I just bought batteries the other day, would like to be able to go on Amazon and have the Amazon site only for Amazon batteries, and then have the Amazon reseller site only for other batteries?

Nobody would want that, and yet, there are calls for breaking up Amazon into two separate sites, one for resellers or marketplace, and the other Amazon products only. I just wanna leave you with one last thought on this, which is, Nick--I think Nick Clegg I guess, who now works for Facebook, he had been Head of, I think the Liberal Party in the U.K. And he raised this point last week I believe, which is a point we've raised for many, many years: if you break up big tech, essentially what you're doing is you're opening up the field for China big tech.

Because I can guarantee you that China is not breaking up their big tech. If anything, what China is going is asking for and encouraging more consolidation in Chinese tech companies. We've been down this road before with utterly disastrous consequences. We reviewed that literature in our book and there's a number of very good studies from academics that actually show that as firm size increases, inequality goes down. Countries with bigger firms have less inequality than countries with small countries. So, it's both longitudinally and across countries.

Secondly, the fact that I love the best on this, is there a very good study that showed the top 15 hedge funds or managers, or financial types, earn more than the top 500 CEO's combined. Those CEO's include people like Tim Cook. So, you know, the idea that somehow inequality is growing, which is true and it's a problem that's true. But, somehow why focus only on this sector, why focus on big. The evidence really, I don't think is very compelling, but-- Actually just--

Since you raised that it, its important to raise, to go to the facts. So, I published something on that recently, report looking at tax robots. And we looked at that data. When you look at that, it's just simply not true. When you review the--at least in the US, when you review the bureau of economic analysis on income shares, what you find is that the labor share of income has gone down.

Now, why is that? Everybody down on the left or their Brandiesian, well labor share of income has gone down because capital share has gone up. It's actually not true. What went up are two things, rent--rent here, income went up. Landowners, building owner income went up. That's not tech companies. And secondly, proprietor income went up. More people are self-employed, or there's more self-employment income. So the notion that labor income went down because capital income went up, it's really just not true.

Other questions?

Right here and then here.

So, why don't we do two questions at a time? We'll try to get through everybody and keep our responses really short.

QUESTION: Ok. Cool. Tom Strubel from R Street Institute. Question about the politicization of anti-trust. So, anti-trust laws are being enforced by private plaintiffs, state AG's. But, at the federal level, we have the FTC and DOJ, who both have terminus jurisdiction because criminal trust enforcement won't be done by DOJ. But, broadly, we have two anti-trust enforcers at the federal level, and they don't always have the same ideas about certain anti-trust issues. And at least one of them is an Executive Branch agency that technically could be directed by the president. There's been a long, you know, practice of the president not interfering in the DOJ's anti-trust work. But, there's suspicion about the AT&T, Time Warner merger.

And we've talked about the future of presidential candidates directing anti-trust enforcement. Some people have proposed moving all federal anti-trust enforcement to the FTC independent agency to remove that possible political interference, or at least reduce it. I'd be curious to hear the panel's thoughts on that proposal.

ATKINSON: Why don't we just do the second question?

Right here.

QUESTION: Hi, my name's Avery James(SP), I'm an intern at Niskanen(SP) Center, and a rising senior at American University. My quick question is that--there we go--I want to know specifically; Seth Bloom gave some great examples about a lot of problems that aren't anti-trust problems. And I just was wondering if you could elaborate about what anti-competitive things are concern? The recent story, I just want to bring to mind is there's some worries about for example, Google using a third-party vendor with Lyrics(SP) genius, I believe that puts special water marks of sorts. Lyrics had found they made their way into Google's automatic result. I'm curious like how you analyze that as like bad for consumers or good.

Thanks.

ATKINSON: Seth, why don't you also take the first one.

BLOOM: Let me address--let me address the first one first.

And I completely agree with the notion that it's a crazy system we have. That we have two agencies enforcing the same law. One of them, part of the Executive Branch, one of them is an independent agency. I would favor having the FTC as the sole anti-trust agency. And actually, in the year 2000 when I first started working in the Senate, I rode into an oversight hearing speech of Senator Paul(SP), my boss saying, why are there two anti-trust agencies?

So, I'm glad to see now that people are talking about this. But I think it's a--this is a historical accident. The SHERMAN Act and CLAYTON Act were passed, the DOJ had the authority to do this. The FTC Act, to enforce that law, the FTC Act was passed in 1914, actually the same time as the CLAYTON Act. And then the FTC also had the authority to enforce the anti-trust laws. They didn't really think at the time that the inconsistencies, at least bureaucratic fights, (INAUDIBLE). It's a crazy system, however, to change it would take an act of Congress, which I don't think is very likely, unfortunately. Although, Senator Lee(SP) has talked about this recently, because the institutional prerogatives of members of Congress, the Judiciary Committee, the oversight of the Justice Department, Commerce Committee with oversight over the FTC, neither want to see their powers revoked.

So, that's how I'd respond to that. I don't think there's a good answer for you, that's just the system.

As to your point, by the way, so hate to be a descending voice, because we've all been totally in agreement. But I don't mean to say that I don't think there's a role for anti-trust investigations of some of these companies. And one of them that I think is really warrants anti-trust scrutiny, and perhaps anti-trust action, not break up, but anti-trust action, is Google. And I've been very personally very vocal in that. In fact, when I was on the anti-trust subcommittee, we had the first hearing in 2011 on this issue. And there are expert testimony that led to the FTC investigation. I think there's a lot of cause for concern about Google. And I think these sanctions, I generally agree with.

And particularly, and I think Google of all these companies is the one company that has to worry. And particularly, you mentioned that issue is an issue that I think is worthy of an investigation. But, the issue of the android operating system, and that Google telling phone manufacturers you have to put Google apps and not install competitors apps. Well, in 1998, the Justice Department brought a pretty similar case that was against Microsoft. And it was because Microsoft was telling OEM's, original equipment manufacturers, computer manufacturers, that they had to preinstall software that was Microsoft software and not substitute Internet Explorer, and not install competitor software, such as Netscape Navigator, which essentially destroyed Netscape Navigator. But they contended that was an effort from Microsoft to maintain its monopoly.

As I said earlier, that didn't result in a breakup, but it resulted in a court of appeals decision, the DC circuit saying, yes that was anti-competitive conduct. And I think for that reason, we have that DC circuit precedent. That puts Google in a lot of, a lot of concerns here. And the DOJ didn't take that investigation to do nothing.

(LAUGHTER)

ATKINSON: I want to turn over to Alec but thank you.

By the way, if you're interested in that, there's a great podcast called Business Wars. And it's just competition between businesses. And one of them is on Netscape versus Microsoft, a really deep dive, it's like five-part series, a lot of fun.

Alec?

STAPP: Just quickly--I'm glad you brought up the Google Genius case. I think a lot of the facts are still in dispute. But from what we know today I think this is a great example of how some people might call an anti-trust issue, but its really a copyright intellectual copyright issue. And from what we do know right now is, that Google also licensing the underlying lyrics itself. And it works with a service called Lyric find to get those lyrics. And so, maybe there is some way that Genius content got caught up in Google's algorithm and maybe there's a problem to be fixed there. But, under current law they have not violated copyright law because they licensed underlying lyrics themselves. And so far, if there is a problem there, it can be handled in a copyright domain, not an anti-trust domain.

OXMAN: And I think Google came out and said that they were addressing that specific problem with an algorithm fix.

SCHREPEL: May I add something on the first question? Can you hear me?

ATKINSON: Yeah.

SCHREPEL: Yeah, very briefly. Looking from you know your system from the outside, it does look weird to have two agencies and take a lot of time to understand why. But what I've done is that I also I'd look at the actual projects of those agencies. And what you see is that its prickly correlated to the amount of fines they impose. And actually send the budget request to the Congress, it's the first and almost the only thing that mention is that, oh last year we done so well, give us more money, basically.

And I think while it will be interesting to think instead of maybe, you know, indeed thinking of another act to combine those two agencies, to find probably a new way to assess whether or not they draw as they should, instead of just focusing on the amount of sanctions. And there are different ways to do that, but I guess it's a different topic, so. But, that's the most interesting issue, I think.

ATKINSON: Ok.

There's a question here.

QUESTION: Hi. Max Filling and I work with M Lex. This question is directed at Thibault. Although, Alec, I believe you'll probably have some input on this. But you said that there is, we don't really have any way of understanding whether breaking up big tech would be good or better consumers in the current state of play. But we do have sort of precedent in breaking up the big tech sector, like the big tech sector of the time. I believe it was Jason that mentioned the AT&T case. And so, I'm wondering what the difference is now between, you know, these brand-new social media companies and the big tech of yester year?

SCHREPEL: Yes. Do you have two hours to answer that?

(LAUGHTER)

No, I think--well, first I think two different things. The first is that its interesting to get to know why the companies in a dominant position. Let's say they are. I'm not even discussing whether or not they are. Let's say big tech are in a dominant position. Do they get dominant position from what they've done in the market or because at some point they were helped by the government? I would say one difference. And the other one is the network effect. And you know, actually a good paper was published, an article in the Wall Street Journal explaining if you were to break up tech companies because of network effects, you will have ten different pieces and one of them will become as big as the previous one. So, not only it's something that is not desirable, but it also ineffective, probably. So, I would say that's probably the main difference.

But, once again, two hours will be

STAPP: And one small point there. I think it shows the analogy that AT&T was broken up into--as part of the breakup, in addition to many other remedies. When they broke up into seven regional monopolies, and then over time because it makes sense to have national telephone network, they merged back together. We saw multiple phone networks today. But I think you see the same thing if you had a northwest Facebook, a southwest Facebook, they would merge together, or one of them would dominate the other.

ATKINSON: I think also to add to that question though, it is an important which I was going to ask the panel, we haven't talked about it. And that's market definition. Market of AT&T was really calling to the customer. I would argue that market for Google and Facebook is the ad market, that's the relevant market to look at with regard to concentration. And do these companies have market power that's distorted in that? And you could argue they don't. I think they're account for 25 percent of the total ads. It's a lot, but, it's not--

Any comments on sort of how we should think about market definition going forward?

BLOOM: Well, market definition is absolutely a crucial issue. I might disagree with you on that comment because of the effect on Google. Yes, the ad market is harder there, if you're a company trying to market your wares, where you are on Google search engine ranking is crucial. If you're on page 12, no one is going to see you.

ATKINSON: Well, that's a conduct issue, Seth.

BLOOM: Right. But--

ATKINSON: --structure--

BLOOM: --but I think what I'm saying is that its more than just the ad market. I'm not sure what the market is there, I'd have to think more about that. But, that sort of goes beyond the ad market. I think the ad market's very important. I guess that's my only point.

STAPP: I would almost phrase that as what's the job to be done here. I'm a business, the job to be done by advertising, marketing or the organic reach, is the job you done is to reach my customers. I think that almost asks for a broader market definition. And as we know, a broader market definition leads to results showing less market power, possibility to raise prices and lower output.

SCHREPEL: If I may on that, because we just the Google cases. It was quite surprising to say the least to see the European Commission decision in the (INAUDIBLE) case, the second one saying that Android is not competing with Google, with Apple iOS, because Apple iOS, the iPhone is more expensive than what Android phones usually are. Therefore, its not the same market. I mean, in the end, if you were to divide up something, you'd totally (INAUDIBLE) that application for, both right? Because you want to reach the maximum consumers. It's not super convincing and I'm actually super interested in seeing in the future, now that we know that iOS and Android is not in the same market, they were having to have the merger case at some point, how the European Commission will actually deal with the issue.

Now, that I've said that--

ATKINSON: And we'll also Will, let you have the last question, but you know, we shouldn't forget supertarian(PH) dynamics. I think several of the speakers, Seth, you raised that. We shouldn't forget that Cymbian(SP) was the largest operating system, probably nobody what knows what Cymbian is. But it was the Nokia operating system, and there was actually--right before Nokia jumped off the pool headfirst with no water, they was a lot of concern about monopoly with them. And oh, we should bring a monopoly case. And probably not a good idea.

QUESTION: Will Rinehart, Center for American Action Forum. Everyone here has kind of talked about this Warren Medium post. And the one thing that I actually find that (INAUDIBLE) people have talked about is their second effective policy remedy that exists within it, which is effectively a neutrality mandate. And that kind of reminds me, at least, you know, conjures up in my mind the fact that a lot of the conversation has also tended towards some sort neutrality mandate or inoperability mandate. And more specifically, an inoperability mandate for some of these larger platforms. I think, personally, that's the much more likely scenario. But I'm just wondering if you think that, that's something that actually probably pass, like a Congressional muster.

Because, I mean we talk about telecom, we're talking about unbundling. And obviously, there's a whole bunch of varieties of this. But, basically, mandating that a certain kind of neutrality or service is--occurs between these competitors, seems to be much more of a likely outcome and a likely policy. And I'm just wondering if you have thoughts on that.

OXMAN: Yeah. I think there--that was an interesting part of her proposal. And I'm glad you drew the telecom analogy, because what you're talking about is common carriage. And that was the--that was the bargain that AT&T struck with the government, right?

Exactly. We'll give you--the government will you give a grant of monopoly, we'll give you access to polls and ducts, and conduits. You can string your wires, we'll insulate you from competition, from any other facility, we'll guarantee you 100 percent market share. But, in exchange for that you have to agree to serve everyone at regulated prices. And AT&T said, well sounds good. And that lasted for 125 years.

Frankly, I don't think that's a particularly good model. And the reason that model is not applicable to the technology companies that we're talking about today is because, they actually arrived at their positions by innovating, not by the government putting a thumb on the scale to their benefit. So, the idea that the government would regulate, whether it's content or interoperability, or portability of data, or whatever it is that the government seeks to do, I think the question you have to ask is why would anyone want to strike that bargain. Why would they want the government to step in and regulate?

In the case of AT&T, it was because in the absence of that, the government made a policy decision that rural America would never had access to the telecom service in the absence of common carriage. Because AT&T wouldn't have an incentive to invest in rural areas unless they were guaranteed 100 percent market share, and that worked out well for as long as it did. I think in the technology industry; those incentives are not necessary. The tech industry isn't asking for government to insulate them against competition, quite the opposite, in fact. And therefore, that kind of bargain I don't think makes sense here.

ATKINSON: Great.

Unless there's a burning desire to make a last comment.

No?

Well ,I want to thank a great panel here. Really, really insightful. And Thibault, thank you for joining us from afar, and your insights into European anti-trust policy, in particular. Thank you all for coming. So please join me in thanking a great panel.

(APPLAUSE)

Information Technology And Innovation Foundation Holds Webinar On The Fcc And Internet Companies Liability

June 17, 2020 12:00 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

ITIF VICE PRESIDENT DANIEL CASTRO

FCC COMMISSIONER GEOFFREY STARKS

[*]CASTRO: Hello, and welcome to today's webinar. My name is Daniel Gastro and I'm vice president of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation. For those of you who do not know ITIF, we're a Washington, D.C.-based think tank focused on the intersection of technological innovation and public policy. So today we're going to be talking about Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The law simply states that no provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider.

So, in short, this just means that online services are not legally responsible for all the things that others might say or do on their services. The law also says that online services should not be held liable for any actions taken in good faith to restrict access to objectionable material.

So, you know, these provisions have enabled U.S. Internet companies to thrive and it allows online services like social media platforms to moderate user content. Some critics say the law is too broad or the courts have interpreted the law too broadly. Most recently on May 28, a few days after Twitter fact checked some of President Trump's tweets, the president signed an Executive order pushing for various changes to online intermediary liability. Along these--the Executive order specifically tasked NTIA with petitioning the FCC to propose regulations to clarify when Section 230 may not apply because of sites editorial decisions and how to interpret the good faith requirement of law.

So, here to discuss the FCC's response today is Commissioner Geoffrey Starks. Commissioner Starks was confirmed to the commission last year. Prior to this he helped lead the FCC's Enforcement Bureau. He's also served as a senior advisor to the deputy attorney general at the Department of Justice. And, you know, throughout his term at the FCC he's been a lead voice on a variety of issues including the national security policy of U.S. communications networks, the need to address security in small and rural networks and the importance of protecting personal privacy as the nation advances and deploys advanced networks and other emerging technologies.

So, Commissioner Starks, a huge thanks for joining us today. I just want to turn it over to you for some--your initial thoughts and comments on this topic.

STARKS: Well, thank you so much for the introduction, Daniel. Thank you to ITIF certainly for organizing this event. Earlier this year, pre-COVID, seems like a lifetime ago, ITIF hosted me for a conversation in Puerto Rico where we had the chance to talk about, amongst those many interesting topics, communications resiliency.

And in preparing our communication networks to withstand all kinds of emergencies, a critical topic certainly for Puerto Rico, has been on my mind lately, of course, again with the hurricane season approaching and COVID-19 continuing to create unprecedented demand and so now, more than ever, the FCC, I think, must stay focused on closing the digital divide as its top priority and it's really not even close. You know, our longstanding digital divide has morphed into a monstrous COVID-19 divide. Internet inequality has magnified and deepened other inequities in our society. The pandemic has made the lack of access to online work, school, healthcare even more unacceptable.

And so with such a big challenge in front of the FCC you might ask why we're talking today about content moderation in social media a very good question. And so in my conversation here and--and--and following, going to talk about some of the issues that I think have developed obviously around 230, how it's arrived at the FCC's doorstep, what we should do about it. Debates in the liability shield embodied in Section 230 have been hotly contested for a number of years now. Section 230, of course, as you previewed, as Congress' deliberate balancing of free speech, privacy, innovation and security concerns and so it's no surprise that different folks, different stakeholders, would strike that balance differently. The direct presidential intervention in that debate is new. And as you mentioned on May 28, President Trump signed an Executive order that, we'll generously call it, takes a novel approach.

And for those who haven't read it in detail, here's the CliffsNotes version, the short version, the Executive order does really three things; first, you know, it directs the executive agencies to report to OMB within 30 days what funds they spent on marketing on online platforms presumably, so the president can direct them to stop spending money on--on those platforms that he deems to be, you know, "problematic vehicles" for government speech due to viewpoint discrimination, deception and other "bad practices."

Second, it directs the White House to forward complaints about online platforms censoring political viewpoints to the FTC and Department of Justice for enforcement and reporting and directs the attorney general to work with the state attorney generals on potential enforcement against unfair and deceptive practices and then third, and most relevant obviously for our conversation here today, is that the EO directs NTIA to file a petition within 60 days asking the FCC to make rules clarifying the relationship between Section 230 broad liability shield, in C1 and its protections for good faith in C2, blocking and removal of user content and defining conditions when an ICS providers moderation is not taken in good faith.

So, a--at the outset here, it is worth noting that the Executive order definitely gets one thing right and that is that the president cannot instruct the SEC to do this or anything else. None of the commission's rules require that we start a rulemaking, we're an independent agency, preceding simply because NTIA asked us to do so. The decision is ours alone and there are good reasons for the FCC to stay out of this debate.

So, today I wanted to talk about process first and why the SEC needs to really kind of keep from dragging this Section 230 issue coming to us; keep it from dragging out. Second, I want to move on to the question of the SEC's rulemaking authority here and then finally I want to raise some key questions around the substance of the Executive order itself. And so first, you know, without delay, I want to address the SEC's process and the timeline for handling rulemaking that the Executive order envisions. And given the role Section 230 has played in shaping American life online, we have to get this right. We need to act quickly.

And so for better or for worse, social media companies targeted in the Executive order play a vital role in our elections. R. Kelly Garrett, a professor at Ohio State found that in 2016, "More Americans named Facebook as the site they most often use for political information in the month leading up to Election Day in 2016 than named any other site including those high profile news organizations such as Fox, CNN and major national newsp--newspapers." That describes, obviously, a sea change in how Americans learn about the world.

And so in 2012, only 40 percent of Americans reported using social media for political purpose. And so whatever you think of the merits of the Executive order, it represents the president's clear intention to influence how social media companies operate at a time when their decisions are heavily impacted in his own electoral future.

And so many commentators have noted that if the FCC is not unusually expeditious in its work, NTIA's petition will likely hang around through Election Day. The president gave NTIA until basically the end of July to send the petition to the FCC and so if we take the usual few weeks to process it, see comment in mid-August, we could easily end up with comment deadlines that are into October and from there the schedule is exclusively at the chairman's discretion. And so he may deem it best that the commission continue to wait before taking any additional steps in the rulemaking process.

But the timeline initiated solely subject with such discretion it seems inevitable that a dark cloud over online free speech the Executive order represents will cast a lingering shadow over our election--elections. So what should the FCC do to avert this looming burden on our democratic process? I believe we should make a decision and move on as quickly as possible. At its core, the Executive order is an attempt to work the rest as many have said, and more than that, I think, get them to swallow the whistle. And so clearly delay itself in resolving a pending rulemaking in this politically fraught conte--context, risks producing a chilling effect construed to make social media companies less willing to flag this information.

And so to help ensure that the EO doesn't interfere with our elections in the fall, I think we should press, and I'm calling to press, NTIA to send the petition as quickly as possible. I see no reason that they should need more than the 30 days from the Executive orders issuance itself so that we can get on with it, have the FCC review it and vote. And if it--if, as I suspect it ultimately will, the petition falls at a legal question of authority, I think we should say so loud and clear, close the book on this unfortunate detour and get back to the important work of closing the digital divide. The worst case scenario, one that burdens the proper functioning of our democracy, would be to allow, you know, the laxity here to bestow some type of credibility on the Executive order, one that threatens certainly a new regulatory regime upon Internet service providers with no credible legal support. And if this is as important as the highest office of the land suggests, then we need to prioritize it, reach a decision expeditiously as possible for our democracy.

And so while the chairman and I may disagree, untimely, on the legal merits here, I would hope that he does agree that the American public deserves our answer this summer and that we should not let this linger during the height of our 2020 elections.

On the second front here, while I do remain, obviously, open-minded about any forthcoming petition that the Department of Comm--Commerce may send my way as an FCC commissioner, based upon my review, I am skeptical that there's any role for the commission to act here as a creature of Congress, the FCC only has the authority given to it by staff statute.

And so we get the power to act when Congress expressly tells us to do something when it leaves an interpretive gap for the FCC to fill and I don't think either has happened here. On its face the statute does not give or direct the FCC, or anyone really, to make rules. Given that historical context, I think that makes a lot of sense. Section 230 was adopted in response to court cases that considered whether early interactive computer services, in those days obviously mainly CompuServe, Prodigy, whether they could ultimately be held liable for content posted by their users. Some of those cases made liability continent on the platforms decision to moderate content instead of acting merely as a passive platform. And as the statute itself explains, Section 230's authors wanted platforms to remove offensive content, create a family-friendly corner of the Internet and they worry that these early cases, the early law incentivized platforms not to.

NTIA, others might argue that Congress has left a gap for the FCC to fill by not defining good faith. That would be their hook. And that phrase might be vague in some context; here, however, you know, I really think there are strong arguments that no gap filling was intended. Section 230 provides a self-enforcing rule for courts to apply and private litigation. It does not really give the FCC an enforcement or administrative role and that's instructive, that's relevant here because good faith, or the lack thereof, is such a commonly litigated issue as well in contact cases. It seems entirely ordinary that Congress would have intended a court to undertake that analysis when evaluating Section 230 defense, and moreover, as I read the subsection, good faith here plays a sem--similar role to its use in contracts limiting what would otherwise be an entirely subjective assessment of whether an ICS provider considers something to be obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, excessively violent, harassing, or the catch all here, otherwise objectionable.

So, third here, my--my third point, if the commission does proceed with a rulemaking, we will have to confront challenging substantive questions; perhaps most importantly the Executive orders approach raises serious First Amendment concerns and focusing on Section 230 we shouldn't lose site of the fact that the Constitution, not just merely a statute, protects private actors right to label, moderate, otherwise control speech on their platforms.

The First Amendment allows social media companies to sensor content, freely, in ways that the government never could and it prohibits the government from retaliating against them for that speech. So much, so much of what the president proposes here seems inconsistent with those core principles in making an FCC rulemaking even less desirable.

And so we'll also need to address how Section 230's rules would fit into the commissions larger regulatory framework; particularly in a world without open Internet rules. There are plenty of things about that status quo that I would change and I want to be clear that I think content discrimination by ISP raises questions that are wholly inapplicable to social media companies, but for those supporters out there of the restoring Internet freedom order, there will be difficult questions ahead about how to square their previous reliance on Section 230(b), the policy statements as a justification for divesting the commission of authority with the president's approach.

They'll also need to consider that ISP's are interactive computer services subject to Section 230 and the president's proposed rules. Those pieces really don't fit together neatly. You can't pretend to have a light touch regulatory framework when you're regulating content with a heavy hand. And so finally we have to be mindful of how broad the consequences of FCC action could be; consider, of course, the ten most popular websites in the United States as of 2018, Professor Jeff Kosseff noted in his book, that six of those primarily rely on videos, social media posts and other user content; that's YouTube, Facebook, Reddit, Wikipedia, Twitter and eBay. And if the liability shield under Section 230 were pierced, these platforms and business models would have to fundamentally change. Congress created Section 230 because it wanted those places to offer something less than a user generated free for all. A world where interactive computer services risk liability for removing offensive content would radically alter those sites. The FCC would need to be extraordinary, extraordinarily careful about upsetting the balance Congress created. And so that's not to say that there's no room for debate here, the broader debate about Section 230 long predates President Trump's conflict with Twitter in particular, and there are so many smart people who believe the law here should be updated.

I share the concern that Section 230 has, at times, been used to immunize criminal behavior; left victims of stalking, harassment and--and much worse without an effective remedy, moreover, particularly as a parent of young children.

I do share the desire to maintain strong incentives for companies to keep some places online safe for kids and these are very valid concerns and they do deserve a robust examination and debate but ultimately that debate belongs to Congress. Congress laid out the original scope of Section 230, the liability shield. I think Congress should decide whether to change it and that the president might find it more expedient to influence a five-member commission than a 538-member Congress is not a sufficient reasons, much less a good one, to circumvent the constitutional function of our democratically elected representatives.

And so let me close by saying, unlike many of the spectrum issues that NTIA in particular handles, I don't think this is a complicated technical issue. And so I call on NTIA, the chairman, to bring this issue before us as quickly as possible and right now. Let us be clear with the American public about what, if any, real world impact this Executive order has, let us avoid an upcoming election season in which the government can use a pending proceeding to, in my estimation, intimidate private parties. Thank you.
